content:
A lass="word-wrap-span">SUPERTANKER lass="word-wrap-span">LOADED with oil headed east from the lass="word-wrap-span">Strait of lass="word-wrap-span">Gibraltar into the Mediterranean, bound for lass="word-wrap-span">Greece, just before midnight on lass="word-wrap-span">August 18th. Nothing unusual in that—some 120,000 vessels pass through the lass="word-wrap-span">Strait each year, carrying a third of the world’s oil and gas. lass="word-wrap-span">But the Iranian-lass="word-wrap-span">flagged lass="word-wrap-span">Adrian lass="word-wrap-span">Darya 1 was no ordinary tanker.

lass="word-wrap-span">Just days earlier she had been renamed and relass="word-wrap-span">flagged, with fresh paint covering her old identity, lass="word-wrap-span">Grace 1 . lass="word-wrap-span">Those actions accompanied lass="word-wrap-span">The vessel’s release from over a month of lass="word-wrap-span">detention in lass="word-wrap-span">Gibraltar, an overseas territory of lass="word-wrap-span">Britain. lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">episode not only marks lass="word-wrap-span">The latest chapter in lass="word-wrap-span">The increasingly bitter struggle between Iran and lass="word-wrap-span">America—which made a final effort to seize lass="word-wrap-span">The ship hours before she set sail—but also highlights lass="word-wrap-span">Britain’s increasingly strained effort to balance its Iran policy between lass="word-wrap-span">American lass="word-wrap-span">belligerence and lass="word-wrap-span">European emollience.

lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">backdrop to lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">crisis is lass="word-wrap-span">President lass="word-wrap-span">Donald lass="word-wrap-span">Trump’s withdrawal last year from lass="word-wrap-span">The multinational nuclear agreement that his predecessor, Barack Obama, had reached with Iran in 2015. lass="word-wrap-span">This agreement had limited Iran’s nuclear programme in exchange for a partial lifting of sanctions.

lass="word-wrap-span">American sanctions on Iran were tightened sharply in lass="word-wrap-span">April under Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump’s policy of “maximum pressure”. lass="word-wrap-span">Moreover, any foreign firms lass="word-wrap-span">That do business with Iran also face the threat of punishment. lass="word-wrap-span">That prompted Iran to walk away from elements of the pact and to hit back in other ways. In lass="word-wrap-span">May lass="word-wrap-span">America and several of its allies blamed Iran for mine attacks on ships in the lass="word-wrap-span">Gulf of lass="word-wrap-span">Oman. lass="word-wrap-span">Matters almost came to a head when Iran shot down an lass="word-wrap-span">American spy lass="word-wrap-span">drone on lass="word-wrap-span">June 20th, causing Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump to order—and then cancel—air strikes on Iran.

lass="word-wrap-span">That was lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">febrile atmosphere on July 4th, when British marines lass="word-wrap-span">abseiled onto lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">deck of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Adrian lass="word-wrap-span">Darya 1 in lass="word-wrap-span">Gibraltarian waters. lass="word-wrap-span">They did so on lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">basis of lass="word-wrap-span">American intelligence suggesting lass="word-wrap-span">That lass="word-wrap-span">The tanker’s oil was bound for lass="word-wrap-span">Syria, whose main refinery is under EU sanctions. On July 19th, after weeks of naval shadow-boxing, Iran procured a bargaining chip of its own by grabbing a British tanker, lass="word-wrap-span">The Stena Impero , in lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Strait of lass="word-wrap-span">Hormuz on spurious charges of safety violations.

lass="word-wrap-span">That may have strenglass="word-wrap-span">Thened Iran’s hand. lass="word-wrap-span">But it was not until Iran promised lass="word-wrap-span">That lass="word-wrap-span">The tanker would not be sent to lass="word-wrap-span">Syria, or any olass="word-wrap-span">Ther destination covered by EU lass="word-wrap-span">Sanctions—promises lass="word-wrap-span">extracted after weeks of lass="word-wrap-span">intense lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">diplomacy involving British and Iranian lass="word-wrap-span">diplomats—lass="word-wrap-span">That lass="word-wrap-span">Gibraltar relented. “In light of lass="word-wrap-span">The assurances we have received,” said lass="word-wrap-span">The territory’s chief minister on lass="word-wrap-span">August 15th, “lass="word-wrap-span">There are no longer any reasonable grounds for lass="word-wrap-span">The continued legal lass="word-wrap-span">detention of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Grace 1 in order to ensure lass="word-wrap-span">compliance with lass="word-wrap-span">The EU lass="word-wrap-span">Sanctions lass="word-wrap-span">Regulation.” lass="word-wrap-span">The ship was accordingly freed.

lass="word-wrap-span">That was a relief to lass="word-wrap-span">Britain. lass="word-wrap-span">The threat of furlass="word-wrap-span">Ther ship-grabs, which had led lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Royal lass="word-wrap-span">Navy to send extra warships to lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Gulf, would lass="word-wrap-span">diminish, and Iran would probably release lass="word-wrap-span">Britain’s tanker in turn. lass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">The drama was not over yet. lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Adrian lass="word-wrap-span">Darya ’s new paint barely dry, when lass="word-wrap-span">America made a last-lass="word-wrap-span">ditch effort to keep lass="word-wrap-span">The heat on Iran. lass="word-wrap-span">The next day, on lass="word-wrap-span">August 16th, a federal court in Washington, DC, issued a warrant for its re-seizure, on lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">basis lass="word-wrap-span">That lass="word-wrap-span">The ship was secretly controlled by a network of companies run by Iran’s lass="word-wrap-span">Islamic lass="word-wrap-span">Revolutionary lass="word-wrap-span">Guard Corps (IRGC), a powerful branch of Iran’s armed forces.

lass="word-wrap-span">America’s legal case reflected both lass="word-wrap-span">The long reach of its sanctions and lass="word-wrap-span">Their unique severity against Iran. In lass="word-wrap-span">April lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Trump administration had lass="word-wrap-span">designated lass="word-wrap-span">The IRGC as a foreign terrorist organisation, against lass="word-wrap-span">The advice of lass="word-wrap-span">American military and intelligence officials. lass="word-wrap-span">The ship’s “lass="word-wrap-span">deceptive voyages” were part of large-scale money-laundering operation, complained lass="word-wrap-span">America’s lass="word-wrap-span">Department of lass="word-wrap-span">Justice. lass="word-wrap-span">That cut no ice with lass="word-wrap-span">Gibraltar. It pointed out lass="word-wrap-span">That lass="word-wrap-span">The EU’s sanctions laws differ from lass="word-wrap-span">America’s, and lass="word-wrap-span">That lass="word-wrap-span">Europeans—like lass="word-wrap-span">The rest of lass="word-wrap-span">The world—treat lass="word-wrap-span">The IRGC as unsavoury actors ralass="word-wrap-span">Ther than outright terrorists.

lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Adrian lass="word-wrap-span">Darya 1 may yet struggle to sell its wares; lass="word-wrap-span">America has threatened to impose sanctions on anyone doing business with her. lass="word-wrap-span">But she has probably escaped lass="word-wrap-span">America’s clutches. lass="word-wrap-span">Even lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Trump administration is likely to rule out nabbing lass="word-wrap-span">The ship in international waters, which would cause an outcry. lass="word-wrap-span">And courts in lass="word-wrap-span">Greece—where she is due to arrive on lass="word-wrap-span">August 25th—will prove no more pliant than those in lass="word-wrap-span">Gibraltar.

lass="word-wrap-span">Nevertheless, the lass="word-wrap-span">diplomatic tussle has put lass="word-wrap-span">Britain in a difficult position. In lass="word-wrap-span">May Hassan Rouhani, Iran’s president, warned that unless the deal’s other signatories—including lass="word-wrap-span">Europe, lass="word-wrap-span">China and lass="word-wrap-span">Russia—helped Iran withstand the tightening vice of lass="word-wrap-span">American sanctions, it would begin steadily violating elements of the deal, inching closer to the ability to build nuclear weapons. It has started to act on that threat. Iran is also said to have warned, privately, that unless it can export 1.5m barrels of oil per day, far more than it does now, it will walk away (oil makes up about a third of Iran’s government budget).

lass="word-wrap-span">Like its lass="word-wrap-span">European allies, lass="word-wrap-span">Britain wants to encourage Iran to remain in lass="word-wrap-span">compliance. It has made sincere efforts to that end. In lass="word-wrap-span">January it spearheaded, with lass="word-wrap-span">France and lass="word-wrap-span">Germany, the creation of Instex, a lass="word-wrap-span">barter mechanism that would lass="word-wrap-span">facilitate certain types of lass="word-wrap-span">Europe-Iran transactions, particularly for lass="word-wrap-span">humanitarian supplies. British lass="word-wrap-span">diplomats say they remain lass="word-wrap-span">eager to soothe Iran with continued trade. lass="word-wrap-span">But the seizure of the lass="word-wrap-span">Adrian lass="word-wrap-span">Darya 1 —with its 2.1m barrels of oil—threw a spanner in the works, not least because lass="word-wrap-span">Britain was prodded into action by lass="word-wrap-span">American intelligence.

lass="word-wrap-span">Furlass="word-wrap-span">Ther complicating matters, lass="word-wrap-span">Britain’s government changed hands midway through lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">crisis; on July 24th, lass="word-wrap-span">Boris lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson succeeded lass="word-wrap-span">Theresa lass="word-wrap-span">May as prime minister, and appointed new foreign and defence ministers. Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson has adopted a lass="word-wrap-span">confrontational attitude to lass="word-wrap-span">European partners over lass="word-wrap-span">The terms of lass="word-wrap-span">Britain’s lass="word-wrap-span">departure from lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">European lass="word-wrap-span">Union, saying lass="word-wrap-span">Britain would leave lass="word-wrap-span">The EU as scheduled on lass="word-wrap-span">October 31st, with or without a deal. He has also courted lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Trump administration, which is keen to encourage Brexit and is holding out lass="word-wrap-span">The prospect of a speedy free-trade deal between lass="word-wrap-span">Britain and lass="word-wrap-span">America to help lass="word-wrap-span">cushion lass="word-wrap-span">The British economy.

lass="word-wrap-span">That leaves lass="word-wrap-span">Britain’s Iran policy in a parlous position. lass="word-wrap-span">Should Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson continue to side with the lass="word-wrap-span">Europeans, he may anger lass="word-wrap-span">America, placing at risk the promise of a post-Brexit economic deal. lass="word-wrap-span">But if he sides with Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump and lass="word-wrap-span">heaps more pressure on Iran, he would risk a complete collapse in the teetering nuclear deal and a spat with lass="word-wrap-span">Europe. “lass="word-wrap-span">You can't maintain lass="word-wrap-span">That post-Brexit lass="word-wrap-span">You'll be a loyal lass="word-wrap-span">ally of lass="word-wrap-span">European nations in matters of security and lass="word-wrap-span">ditch 20 years of Iran policy by moving over to the lass="word-wrap-span">American side,” says Richard lass="word-wrap-span">Dalton, who served as lass="word-wrap-span">Britain's lass="word-wrap-span">amlass="word-wrap-span">bassador to Iran between 2003 and 2006. “If lass="word-wrap-span">Britain is to have any influence in the world, it's got to keep lass="word-wrap-span">intact the relationships with lass="word-wrap-span">France and lass="word-wrap-span">Germany in order to continue to be a bridge between lass="word-wrap-span">America and lass="word-wrap-span">Europe.”

lass="word-wrap-span">Thus far, Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson has continued to seek a balance. lass="word-wrap-span">Whereas Mrs lass="word-wrap-span">May’s government had tried to lass="word-wrap-span">corral a group of lass="word-wrap-span">European states in a maritime-security mission for the lass="word-wrap-span">Persian lass="word-wrap-span">Gulf—in marked preference to one involving lass="word-wrap-span">America—Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson’s government quickly signed up to the lass="word-wrap-span">American-led scheme. lass="word-wrap-span">John lass="word-wrap-span">Bolton, Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump’s national security adviser, visiting lass="word-wrap-span">Britain on lass="word-wrap-span">August 12th, noted with pleasure that the choice “reflects a change from the prior government”. lass="word-wrap-span">But the release of the lass="word-wrap-span">Adrian lass="word-wrap-span">Darya 1 shows that even Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Johnson is unwilling to break with lass="word-wrap-span">European partners and join Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump in trying to throttle Iran. At least not yet.
